results.title: Creatures in clay: ceramic sculpture by Rosemary Wren
results.creator_credit: Films for Potters and J M Anderson Films
results.brief_description: This film about pottery shows in some detail, Rosemary Wren’s technique of building large figures, using T-shaped coils, and making small models by thumbing and pinching.

results.title: Creativity at school
results.brief_description: High school students learn to think creatively in a Technical Activities Centre where they apply what they have learned to model building projects. An experiment in science education at Sevenoaks School in Kent; boys apply the principals learned to creating a variety of models, instruments and machines including wireless controlled model boats and racing cars, an instrument to give blind people signals about their physical environment and a simple computer. The nature of this experiment makes this film an important educational record.

results.title: Creative problem solving: how to get better ideas
results.brief_description: Shows how individuals function with unconscious mental restrictions, and tells how to become free of such restrictions and discover our own creativity, thus increasing the ability to solve problems. Examines several of the common emotional, perceptual, cultural and environmental blocks that limit the quality of out ideas. Looks at problem solving techniques such as ‘brainstorming’ and ‘synectics’, shows how the concepts discussed in the film can be utilised, and explains ways in which management can encourage creativity within an organisation.

results.title: Creative ceramics: using the banding wheel
results.brief_description: The basic fundamentals of working with clay, concentrating on the many valuable uses of the banding or simple decorating wheel. Introduces simple tools, and how they are used - paint brushes, needle point tools, wire loops and even hair combs. Demonstrates the plastic, flexible and manageable qualities of clay.

results.title: Creative art in rural America
results.creator_credit: William James and United States Information Service
results.brief_description: The University of Wisconsin is situated in the town of Madison, in the heart of the Middle West. One of its many educational functions is to inspire and encourage the development of arts and crafts among the many rural groups and communities throughout the State of Wisconsin. Many exhibitions of rural art are arranged and instruction and guidance provided by the resident tutor and the University Extension Department, which sends out art teachers to instruct rural groups throughout the State.

results.title: Creating with shapes
results.creator_credit: Dick Larson and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Objects in nature, man-made objects, children’s art, and famous paintings introduce the three basic shapes: rectangles, triangles and circles. After learning to observe shapes, we see children creating and arranging shapes to form original works of art.

results.title: Creating with clay
results.brief_description: A teacher demonstrates wire and spiral wedging using nylon to string to divide clay. Students create spontaneously - pinch bowls, coil pot, slab draping and decorating, fist forms, texturing and string sculpture.
